summary: This document is an email chain from August 13-14, 2019, between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discussing evidence and legal strategy in the Jeffrey Epstein case. The discussion focuses on the scope of trafficking offenses (confined to Florida), venue issues, potential forfeiture of properties in New York, Florida, and the U.S. Virgin Islands, and the anticipated filing of civil lawsuits under New York's look-back law.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: He is the sender/recipient in the email chain, directing the need for a summary of forfeiture options and a 'cognizable theory' to pursue residences in NY, FL, and VI.

persons.name: M, (USANYS) 3
persons.context: An active participant in the email chain, discussing the accuracy of evidence statements regarding trafficking offenses and victims, and managing communication about forfeiture and civil lawsuits.

connections.description: Professional correspondence within the U.S. Attorney's Office, with Berman giving directives and M providing updates and clarifications on evidence and legal strategy.

events.title: Anticipated civil lawsuit filings
events.description: Multiple attorneys intend to file lawsuits on behalf of clients when the New York State look-back law re-opens the statute of limitations for sex crimes.

events.title: Forfeiture options summary deadline
events.description: Geoffrey Berman requests a summary of forfeiture options regarding Epstein's properties by Thursday morning (August 15, 2019).

keyFacts: Prosecutors state that all conduct related to victims for which they have evidence was confined to Florida, and they lack venue for a substantive count based on other tip line calls.
There is no present evidence of trafficking offenses involving the U.S. Virgin Islands property, pending search warrant results.
The U.S. Attorney's Office is actively developing a legal theory to pursue forfeiture of Epstein's residences in New York, Florida, and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

Civil attorneys planned to file lawsuits starting August 14, 2019, under New York's newly re-opened statute of limitations for sex crimes, and inquired about potential conflicts with government forfeiture actions.
